projectDesc.p: "Menologion Ignatios" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

lem.b: τῆ ἀυτή ἡμέρα μνήμη τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰγατίου πατριάρχου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως

rdg.b: On the same day, in holy remembrance of our father Ignatios, patriarch of Constantinople.

app.lem: Ὁ ἐν ἀγιοις πατὴρ ἡμῶν Ἰγνάτιος, γέγονε μὲν υἱὸσ Μιχαηλ βασιλέωσ, ἀδελφὸσ δὲ θεοφίλου καὶ ἔγγων Νικηφόρου τῶν βασιλέων,
app.rdg:
Our holy father Ignatios had been born son of emperor Michael,
Michael I Rangabe
and [was] brother of emperors Theophilou
Probably Theophylact, eldest son of Michael I Rangabe.
and grandson of Nikephoros.
Nikephoros I

app.lem: ἐυνοῦχοσ δὲ γεγονὼσ, εἶτα καὶ μοναχὸς, γέγονε καὶ ἡγούμενοσ τῆσ μονῆσ τοῦ ἀρχαγγέλου τοῦ τότε μὲν ἐπιλεγομένου ανατέλλοντοσ, νῦν δὲ Σατύρου.
app.rdg:
Having become a eunuch and then a monk, he had become hegoumenos of the monastery of the archangel, the one at times called ascendant,
ie. Michael
now, [the monastery] of Satyros.
Just outside of Constantinople; See Barsanti and Alessandra Ricci, "The road from Baghdad to Byzantium and the case of the Bryas palace in Istanbul," in Byzantium in the Ninth Century: Dead or Alive?: Papers from the Thirtieth Spring Symposium of Byzantine Studies, Birmingham, March 1996, ed. Leslie Brubaker (Aldershot and Bookfield: Ashgate, 1998)..

app.lem: Εἲτα προεχειρίσθη και πατριάρχησ Κωνσταντινουπόλεως, καὶ ἐκράτησεν ἔτη ἔνδεκα μῆνας πέντε, καὶ μετὰ τᾶυτου ἐξεβλήθη ὑπὸ Μιχαὴλ βασιλέως, ἀντ᾽ἀυτοῦ πατριάρχην ποιήσαντος.
app.rdg: Then he was made patriarch of Constantinople, and he ruled for eleven years and five months; and then he was overthrown by emperor Michael who made Photios patriarch instead of him.
Photios first became [for his own benefit] a monk.

app.lem: ἔιτα ἐξεβλήθη καὶ ἀυτὸσ ὑπὸ βασιλέιου βασιλέως, καὶ αντικατέστη Ἰγνάτιοσ πάλιν, καὶ ἐπεσκόπηασιν ἔτη ἔνδεκα, κὰι πάλιν εξεβλήθη.
app.rdg: Then, he [Photios] was exiled by the king of kings, and Ignatios was brought back again and held the office for eleven years and was overthrown again.

app.lem: κὰι ἐγένετο πατριάρχης Στέφαωος ὅ ἐν ἁγίοις υἱοσ βασιλέιου βασιλέως.
app.rdg: And Saint Stephen, the son of the king of kings, became patriarch.

app.lem: ὀ δὲ ἅγιοσ Ἰγάτιος ἀπελθών έν τῶ τοῦ σατύρου μοναστηρίω καὶ καλῶς βιώσας ἐν ἐρήνη ἐτελειώθη:
app.rdg: Thus, Saint Ignatios went away to the monastery of Satyros, and he lived well and rested in peace.
